job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: A lot of flexibility and independence with your daily tasks. Great team and work environment. Staff is very supportive and management actually cares about you. There are times where they have staff lunches and events.
cons: Some documentation requirements seem unnecessary. That and management can be challenging to contact at times.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: The people are committed to the mission of helping families experiencing homelessness. Everyone there has a good heart and is trying to make the world a better place.
cons: As with all nonprofits, there is more need and work than people to do it. It takes a dedicated, committed individual who has a larger purpose in life to be a good fit here. The work is emotional and tiring, but the results are amazing - especially for the children that we help - there is no better feeling than seeing them get a home of their own.

job_title: Residential Counselor in San Francisco, CA
pros: Mission driven organization - if you want to make an impact on ending homeless, this is the place. Put your passion into overdrive! Pay is more competitive now. Professional development is actively encouraged. Agency is working on being more in tune to diversity, equity, and inclusion. Love what it’s done to the culture here. Helping someone who’s experiencing homelessness warms my heart! Makes all the work amazing.
cons: Work is demanding and takes a lot out of you. Passion fuels but refueling is needed along the way. Agency is always changing which can make consistency in effort challenging.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Hamilton Families is a first rate shelter for individuals experiencing homelessness. We are blessed with great top tier management and it flows downward. We have excellent healthcare, lots of training, good vacation time and promotions from within. Your heart needs to be invested in the company’s mission, but if it is I highly recommend working here!
cons: We are open 24/7 365 so you will work some days you'd rather not.

review_title: You get out of it what you put into it
job_title: Housing Stability Specialist in San Francisco, CA
pros: This job is all about the work you put into it! If you're a hard worker and go getter you'll do just fine. If you're in it because you truly care for the community then you'll always go home feeling GREAT. Some days get tough but that's something bound to happen at every job.
cons: Long hours!! It can get overwhelming so make sure to practice your self care routine.

pros: Hamilton Families is a well-known organization and being employed here for any length of time is viewed favorably by other organizations. They have a good reputation amongst other nonprofit homeless service providers and I'm glad to be part of this agency.
cons: Agency is going through a lot of change right now and although management makes an effort to keep us informed, it's a bit difficult to keep up with all the changes.

job_title: Housing Stability Specialist in San Francisco, CA
pros: The job itself is rewarding due to the nature of the work.
cons: It is difficult to accept the fact that in this position you will realize the homeless problem is such an ongoing issue. You must accept the fact that you cannot resolve this issue overnight!

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Lots of great training, passionate insight on important matters, great development opportunities, great people to work with, great work-life balance.
cons: I have nothing bad to say about this company.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Helping others is the best part of this job. Benefits are great and the staff are kind.
cons: Can create anxiety if you don’t understand human behavior.

pros: The company is very mission-oriented. My supervisor was kind and approachable and I felt like a valued employee with a voice. Flexibility in scheduling and an ability to voice concerns.
cons: Turn around time on certain deadlines.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: The company is very mission-oriented. My supervisor was kind and approachable and I felt like a valued employee with a voice. Flexibility in scheduling and an ability to voice concerns.
cons: Turn around time on certain deadlines.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great support and friendly staff. Extremely rewarding. I am 20 years old and have never been so excited to work for an organization I can finally be proud of.
cons: No cons. Just wish more organizations like Hamilton existed.

pros: Hamilton Families is a great place to work and contribute.
cons: As a growing organization, it’s working to keep up with the quick growth.

pros: The work is meaningful and high impact. There is opportunity for growth, both in terms of skill and experience and as it relates to promotions within the organization.
cons: There is a very high volume of work and we are often short staffed.

pros: Caring staff and managers. Hard work but worth it! Great team spirit. Supportive leadership.
cons: Worked with a great team there. I have nothing bad to say about Hamilton Families.

job_title: Residential Counselor in San Francisco, CA
pros: Organized, fun environment. Friendly staff.
cons: Work can be monotonous. Make sure to create a lot of time for breaks.

pros: Good pay, benefits and fulfilling job helping the community
cons: Work expectations can get stressful

pros: Excellent benefits Feels like working with family Management works hard to include input from their teams Mission driven Great group of people to work with!
cons: Smaller agency, so not as much room for growth

review_title: Great place to get your start
pros: Great place to start your path to social services.
cons: Always more to get done than time to get it done in

pros: I liked this job because you got to incorporate your own personal experience and bring it to the clients as well as connect with them.
cons: Large organization – departments felt disconnected at times.

pros: Rewarding to know that you are making a positive impact in the lives of others who have or are experiencing homelessness!
cons: High workloads, there doesn't seem to be sufficient time during the day to get your work done.

pros: Great group of people. Flexible schedule. Company events. Plenty of time off. Work balance is a priority. Management are tough but fair.
cons: Not the easiest job in the world.

pros: HF is committed to ending homelessness and is good at analyzing ways to improve in that endeavor.
cons: The work can be challenging and this can lead to stress on a day to day basis

pros: Great team and supervisors. Professional staff.
cons: None. But can be stressful.

job_title: Housing Stability Specialist (Bilingual) in San Francisco, CA
pros: Coworkers are passionate and most are very nice people. My coworkers were the best part of my job. Union salary and negotiation was good. Generous time off and good benefits.
cons: I was a part of the Heading Home Initiative as a Bilingual Housing Stability Specialist. They hired many people with little experience in social work and homeless services that had little training working with people experiencing trauma. Average turnover rate for Stability Specialist and Navigation Specialists was about a year. While there were some managerial level staff that listened and advocated for staff, the needs of the specialist fell on deaf ears when presented to upper management. At there time there was little diversity in mid and upper level management as well.

job_title: Housing Stability Specialist in San Francisco, CA
pros: Manager was open minded about mental health days. Manager was supportive of second hand trauma case managers experienced.
cons: No room for growth. Nepotism was blatant.

job_title: Residential Counselor in San Francisco, CA
pros:
-most of your coworkers are really great 
-Union Job
-Healthcare is great
cons:
-Office Gossip 
-Management treats employees poorly 
-Most schedules are not ideal

pros: Great work environment and mission.
cons: The communication between departments could improve.

pros: It's fulfilling to work with underserved families and it is really important work.
cons: There are some issues with lack of oversight/management as well as a lot of turnover in staff. Hopefully these have been resolved in recent years. The benefits are excellent but the pay is very low.

job_title: Program Coordinator in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great people working there; great mission
cons: Lack of management transparency; no leadership training; unclear promotion pipeline

pros: Good People , trying to do good work.
cons: Non Profit payscale , but competitive

pros: Non profit that puts a lot of time and energy for the wellbeing of its employees. Employees are passionate and kind. Great benefits
cons: Growing pains, people are overworked like most non profits

job_title: Housing Stability Specialist in San Francisco, CA
pros:
-Flexible schedule
-Committed staff
-Opportunity to make a real impact
cons:
-Lack of organization
-Lack of upward mobility 
-Unclear expectations

job_title: Database Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: great culture & cause. Benefits are also good!
cons: turnover is high and leadership can be obscure

job_title: Housing Stability Coordinator in San Francisco, CA
pros: Generous holiday, vacation and sick pay. Hourly staff are the best around! Great mission. Prominent and well-known nonprofit. Education reimbursement ($1,000 per year) after 1 year of continuous work. Wellness rewards.
cons: Upper management disconnection from the work. Lack of accountability between departments. Lack of communication between upper management. Upper management speaks about striving for feedback and improvement but does not implement the feedback. Coordinators and Specialists/Case Managers are not paid to accommodate the work they are doing. Dependents benefits are not sufficient/are expensive (averaging $500 monthly for spouses).

pros: flexibility, field staff don't always have to stay in an office, coworkers are awesome
cons:
pay is low for a company based in sf and pay increases by year is almost nothing. management is horrible, not supportive or in the office to offer support and there is a huge lack of consistency between middle and upper management, lack of communication as well. management claims there is room for feedback but does not implement change based on staff feedback instead does the exact opposite and can make the job harder than it needs to be. lack of support for field staff, lack of transportation and has unrealistic expectations from staff considering the work we do. 

this job is not the worst job in the world but the pay is ridiculously low for stability specialist and the work load and the program is not built for the families we serve. there needs to be major restructure addressing issues from staff feedback not from higher management that have just been added on to the organization.

review_title: Great Entry Job to get into Social Work
job_title: Housing Navigation Specialist in San Francisco, CA
pros:
- Great team and atmosphere to work in
- Get a chance to be at the forefront of new Rapid Rehousing initiative to alleviate homelessness. 
- Your voice is heard and can affect the structure of the program
- Benefits are pretty good:
   *3 weeks of paid vacation per year (not including the paid Holidays) 
   *11 days of paid sick days
   *insurance, etc.
cons:
- Top executives seem to be not really involved in how our program and services are
- The work itself sometime feels like a bandaid solution

review_title: So much heart and a deep sense of purpose
job_title: Grants Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: I have had a outstanding experience being welcomed as a member of HF’s development team. We are making a big difference in family homelessness and it is an honor to contribute to this work. I will be working alongside many highly accomplished leaders to grow our revenues & to end family homelessness.
cons: Rapid growth means that there are many new systems to learn, but that is positive in some sense and can only help me grow.

job_title: Housing Navigation Specialist in San Francisco, CA
pros: great coworkers, direct service aspect can be rewarding
cons: very poorly managed organization, management disconnected from what is happening on the ground, low pay, bureaucracy makes it hard to accomplish anything, lack of support from supervisors

job_title: Case Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Meaningful work, cool city, very interesting client base, certain employees were pretty amazing people. Good role if you have think skin or want to grow some.
cons: Not livable salary for SF.. Overall experience didn't feel very sustainable or supportive from within. I think if they paid a reasonable salary, this could have been a 3.5 star average rating.

pros:

Easy to work with Staff

cons:

Depending on the location in which you work, public transportation may be difficult to navigate from different working venues (a lot of walking from the  bus)

review_title: The population taught me more than my peers

cons: At times Structurally it seemed as if we where going in different directions not working to accomplish the same goals

pros: Great Development team. They have a close connection to direct work with clients and this is reflected in their fundraising success.
cons: Try new fundraising techniques and good communications to keep donors connected.

pros: Passionate and committed staff at all levels
cons: Needs to build internal capacity to fully implement new programs and initiatives
